Tired of LeetCode interviews? So are we.Let’s talk about the outdated elephant in the room:Live coding sessions with 2–3 people silently judging your every keystroke while you solve an algorithm you’ll never use on the job.This isn’t just uncomfortable — it’s broken.Here’s the data:According to [HackerRank] only 16% of developers use algorithms like those in LeetCode in real work.A [Karat] survey found 74% of candidates feel more anxious during live coding than any other part of the interview.And the kicker? Great devs fail because of nerves — not lack of skill.Real talk:Building software is not a speed sport ⏱️It’s not about solving red-black trees in 25 minutes.It’s about collaboration 🤝, problem solving 🧠, debugging 🐞, and design 🧱 — plus knowing what to Google 🔍.So why are we still doing this?We need a better way:✅ Async take-home projects (paid, of course)✅ Code reviews with real-world context✅ System design walkthroughs✅ Pair programming — but chill✅ Let devs use their real tools (yes, even Copilot)Let’s stop filtering for “LeetCode athletes” and start hiring real-world engineers.Because if your interview process causes more anxiety than the actual job… you’re doing it wrong.hashtag#NoMoreLeetCodehashtag#TechHiringhashtag#DevCulturehashtag#EngineeringInterviewshashtag#LetDevsBreathehashtag#WorkInTechhashtag#BuildBetterTeams

I recently completed the Data Science assessment for the Data Engineer - Data Warehouse role at IBM India, and I wanted to share a glimpse of the experience. The assessment included two challenging questions that really put my skills to the test. The question involved finding the minimum number of swaps to group like units in a circular network of Compute and Network units. I approached this by calculating the minimum swaps needed to group all Compute units together using a sliding window technique, considering the circular nature of the network. It was a rewarding experience, and I’m feeling more motivated than ever....hashtag#IBM hashtag#DataEngineering hashtag#DataWarehouse hashtag#DataScience hashtag#SQL hashtag#Algorithms hashtag#CareerMilestone hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobOpportunity hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#DataDriven hashtag#Engineering hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth hashtag#LinkedIn hashtag#Networking hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#Technology hashtag#Innovation hashtag#Grateful hashtag#Excited hashtag#FutureOfWork

A decade ago, the roles driving today's AI transformation weren't on anyone's radar. Now they form the backbone of every enterprise AI strategy. As Gartner's analysis reveals, the AI workforce landscape has fundamentally transformed:The foundation remains strong with Data Scientists and Data Engineers continuing to provide critical expertise. Meanwhile, we're witnessing the rapid emergence of specialized roles like Prompt Engineers, Model Validators, and Knowledge Engineers that bridge technical implementation with practical application.Most significantly, organizations can no longer succeed without AI Architects, ML Engineers, and AI Risk & Governance Specialists who ensure systems scale responsibly across the enterprise.The reality of modern AI deployment extends far beyond technical proficiency. Success demands cross-functional collaboration that weaves together business strategy, model development, validation protocols, deployment frameworks, and continuous monitoring systems.Organizations positioned for long-term advantage aren't just hiring technical specialists—they're building integrated teams that balance innovation with operational discipline and ethical governance.For professionals navigating career paths or executives assembling teams, the AI opportunity landscape has expanded dramatically in both scope and complexity. “Building Global Teams? Stop Looking for Mirrors. Start Hiring Multipliers”As a global organization expanding into India through our Global Capability Center, you are not just setting up another satellite office, you're building a strategic, innovation-driven extension of business.That demands a mindset shift, especially when it comes to hiring.Too often, I hear: “They’re not the right culture fit.”And what that often really means is: “They don’t think, speak, or act like we do.”But if we’re going to build truly global teams, that’s not a bug, it’s a feature.We can’t expect to scale innovation while hiring only for alignment with HQ norms.That’s not how you unlock the full potential of a capability center in a talent-rich, perspective-diverse market like India.High-performing teams aren’t built by replicating what we already have. They’re built by welcoming what we don’t.What does that look like?➡️ Talent that sees the business challenge differently➡️ Engineers who approach scale with local context and global ambition➡️ Analysts who interpret data through a different cultural lens, and uncover insights we missed🔹 Hiring for culture fit can be a shortcut to sameness.🔸 Hiring for culture add is how we build resilience, creativity, and competitive edge.So next time we say, “They don’t feel like the right fit,”Let’s ask: “Are we really protecting our culture, or just resisting change?”Because in building a GCC, we’re not looking for mirrors.We’re looking for multipliers!hashtag#CultureAdd hashtag#GlobalTeams hashtag#HiringForImpact hashtag#GlobalCapabilityCenter hashtag#InclusiveHiring hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#InnovationThroughDiversity Zinnov

How I caught a £0.40 mistake—and saved the company from losing millions.As a Data Quality Engineer, I’ve always believed that every number tells a story.Recently, while running my routine DQ checks, I spotted a small discrepancy: the online price of a product was £0.40 cheaper than its actual cost. Uncommon Issues in Hiring for the Automotive SectorThe automotive industry encounters distinctive recruitment problems which extend beyond standard skill deficits. The automotive industry faces an uncommon challenge because of its fast transition to electrification which demands knowledge of battery technology and software integration. The lack of specialized skills among experienced automotive engineers produces a significant talent shortage. The reluctance of tech professionals to join traditional automotive companies exists because they prefer working at tech giants which provide remote employment and innovative work environments. The industry faces difficulties in recruiting data scientists and AI experts who are essential for autonomous driving systems because of this perception.The industry faces problems because of differences between generations. The automotive industry faces a challenge because young workers seek roles with sustainability focus and purpose yet they view automotive jobs as traditional and environmentally harmful. This deters passionate candidates. The combination of supply chain disruptions and trade policies restricts the hiring of international talent because certain regions maintain strict visa rules.The market demand for cybersecurity professionals who work on connected vehicles remains unfulfilled because other industries compete more successfully for these experts. The automotive industry needs to transform its branding approach while providing training opportunities and flexible work arrangements to recruit modern talent who will shape the future of the industry.

Username: Jhoshna sai bhargavi ParaJhoshna sai bhargavi Para
Post Content:
Most AI/ML posts talk about accuracy. Real-world AI talks about survival.After deploying multiple models in production, I’ve learned this:A model is not a solution. A system is.Here’s what every experienced ML engineer eventually learns  1.	Clean data beats clever modelsYou can tune hyperparameters all day. Or you can fix broken pipelines and gain 10x accuracy with 1 hour of cleanup. 2.	Feature stores aren’t optional anymoreIf your training and serving pipelines aren’t using the same transformations with point-in-time correctness, you’re risking silent failures. 3.	Offline evaluation ≠ production performanceYour AUC on test data means little if real-time inference suffers from latency, schema mismatches, or concept drift. Always validate in prod. 4.	Monitoring isn’t nice to have — it’s your early warning systemTrack feature drift, data anomalies, and performance decay. If your model degrades silently, so does the user experience. 5.	Model versioning and rollback strategies save careersWithout model registries and CI/CD for ML, you’re one bad deploy away from a business incident. 6.	Feedback loops can destroy your dataIf your model influences what data gets collected, retraining on that biased data just amplifies the problem. Design the loop carefully.⸻The takeaway:Production ML isn’t about building smart models — it’s about building resilient systems that adapt, explain, and earn trust.If you’re building AI that survives the real world, I’d love to connect.If you’re hiring — this is the engineering mindset I bring.hashtag#AI hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#MLOps hashtag#FeatureStores hashtag#ModelMonitoring hashtag#ProductionML hashtag#DataScience hashtag#LLMs hashtag#ModelDeployment hashtag#EthicalAI hashtag#PostToSave hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#Python hashtag#TensorFlow hashtag#AIEngineering

Load balancer – Like a restaurant host assigning tables evenly7. Caching – Saves time like bookmarking a recipe8. CDN – Delivers content from the closest “store”9. Message queues – Like taking a token at a food court10. Using setTimeout() to simulate async behavior? That's an anti-pattern in modern JavaScript.✨ Instead, use Promises or async/await to handle real-world async operations like fetching data, uploading files, or processing payments.👨‍💼 Recruiters want engineers who understand modern asynchronous patterns. Most beginner data analysts focus on tools. The smart ones focus on problems. The best ones focus on impact.If you’re applying for roles in the data analytics space and wondering why your portfolio isn’t getting noticed, read this carefully.A while ago, I was reviewing a job description for a client-side data role. One line caught my attention:➡️ “Use analytics to identify productivity gaps in the frontline sales workforce.”Now, most people would think: “Okay, let me build a dashboard showing number of visits or sales per employee.” And yes, that’s a start, but it’s not value.So I asked myself:📌 What does productivity really mean here?📌 Is it purely about sales numbers or about how many working days were spent effectively?📌 Is there a link between store footfall and visit frequency?📌 What if poor performance isn’t individual, but systemic at the regional or managerial level?That’s when the real project began. Instead of dragging in sample data or public CSVs, I started with a problem definition:“How can we measure Salesforce productivity in context, and not just in aggregate?”Here’s how I broke it down:✅ Compare planned visits (PJP) vs actual visits (AJP)✅ Flag zero-sales days and map against attendance✅ Create a hierarchy-level view — sales rep vs team lead vs regional manager✅ Identify clusters of underperformance✅ Overlay target data to find gaps between activity and outcomeAnd then I asked the golden question:“What would management do with this insight?”The result wasn’t just a dashboard. It was a decision support tool, helping stakeholders:🟢 Prioritize regions for training🟢 Optimize TL-to-employee mapping🟢 Detect ground-level inefficiencies early🟢 Link field behavior to revenue performanceHere’s the lesson:📍 Your project should not just prove you can write SQL or use Power BI.📍 It should prove you understand how businesses think, measure, and act.Start by picking a real business metric, not a dataset. Find a real-world decision problem, and reverse-engineer a solution for it. Frame your project like this:“Here’s the question a stakeholder might ask. Here’s how I’d solve it.”Whether it’s:🔹 Customer retention🔹 Supply chain bottlenecks🔹 Sales effectiveness🔹 Store conversion rate🔹 Marketing ROIYou’re not just an analyst. You’re a problem solver. A business partner. A decision enabler. That’s what hiring managers want to see.Not more dashboards. But more clarity.More thinking.More business fluency.So before your next project… Don’t ask, “What can I build?” Ask, “What problem am I solving?”hashtag#dataanalytics hashtag#dashboard hashtag#powerbi hashtag#dashbaord hashtag#dataanalyst hashtag#businessintelligence

Tired of LeetCode interviews? So are we.Let’s talk about the outdated elephant in the room:Live coding sessions with 2–3 people silently judging your every keystroke while you solve an algorithm you’ll never use on the job.This isn’t just uncomfortable — it’s broken.Here’s the data:According to [HackerRank] only 16% of developers use algorithms like those in LeetCode in real work.A [Karat] survey found 74% of candidates feel more anxious during live coding than any other part of the interview.And the kicker? Great devs fail because of nerves — not lack of skill.Real talk:Building software is not a speed sport ⏱️It’s not about solving red-black trees in 25 minutes.It’s about collaboration 🤝, problem solving 🧠, debugging 🐞, and design 🧱 — plus knowing what to Google 🔍.So why are we still doing this?We need a better way:✅ Async take-home projects (paid, of course)✅ Code reviews with real-world context✅ System design walkthroughs✅ Pair programming — but chill✅ Let devs use their real tools (yes, even Copilot)Let’s stop filtering for “LeetCode athletes” and start hiring real-world engineers.Because if your interview process causes more anxiety than the actual job… you’re doing it wrong.hashtag#NoMoreLeetCodehashtag#TechHiringhashtag#DevCulturehashtag#EngineeringInterviewshashtag#LetDevsBreathehashtag#WorkInTechhashtag#BuildBetterTeams

I recently completed the Data Science assessment for the Data Engineer - Data Warehouse role at IBM India, and I wanted to share a glimpse of the experience. The assessment included two challenging questions that really put my skills to the test. The question involved finding the minimum number of swaps to group like units in a circular network of Compute and Network units. I approached this by calculating the minimum swaps needed to group all Compute units together using a sliding window technique, considering the circular nature of the network. A decade ago, the roles driving today's AI transformation weren't on anyone's radar. Now they form the backbone of every enterprise AI strategy. As Gartner's analysis reveals, the AI workforce landscape has fundamentally transformed:The foundation remains strong with Data Scientists and Data Engineers continuing to provide critical expertise. Meanwhile, we're witnessing the rapid emergence of specialized roles like Prompt Engineers, Model Validators, and Knowledge Engineers that bridge technical implementation with practical application.Most significantly, organizations can no longer succeed without AI Architects, ML Engineers, and AI Risk & Governance Specialists who ensure systems scale responsibly across the enterprise.The reality of modern AI deployment extends far beyond technical proficiency. How I caught a £0.40 mistake—and saved the company from losing millions.As a Data Quality Engineer, I’ve always believed that every number tells a story.Recently, while running my routine DQ checks, I spotted a small discrepancy: the online price of a product was £0.40 cheaper than its actual cost. Uncommon Issues in Hiring for the Automotive SectorThe automotive industry encounters distinctive recruitment problems which extend beyond standard skill deficits. The automotive industry faces an uncommon challenge because of its fast transition to electrification which demands knowledge of battery technology and software integration. The lack of specialized skills among experienced automotive engineers produces a significant talent shortage. The reluctance of tech professionals to join traditional automotive companies exists because they prefer working at tech giants which provide remote employment and innovative work environments. The industry faces difficulties in recruiting data scientists and AI experts who are essential for autonomous driving systems because of this perception.The industry faces problems because of differences between generations. The automotive industry faces a challenge because young workers seek roles with sustainability focus and purpose yet they view automotive jobs as traditional and environmentally harmful. This deters passionate candidates. The combination of supply chain disruptions and trade policies restricts the hiring of international talent because certain regions maintain strict visa rules.The market demand for cybersecurity professionals who work on connected vehicles remains unfulfilled because other industries compete more successfully for these experts. Username: Jhoshna sai bhargavi ParaJhoshna sai bhargavi Para
Post Content:
Most AI/ML posts talk about accuracy. Real-world AI talks about survival.After deploying multiple models in production, I’ve learned this:A model is not a solution. A system is.Here’s what every experienced ML engineer eventually learns  1.	Clean data beats clever modelsYou can tune hyperparameters all day. Or you can fix broken pipelines and gain 10x accuracy with 1 hour of cleanup. 2.	Feature stores aren’t optional anymoreIf your training and serving pipelines aren’t using the same transformations with point-in-time correctness, you’re risking silent failures. 3.	Offline evaluation ≠ production performanceYour AUC on test data means little if real-time inference suffers from latency, schema mismatches, or concept drift. Always validate in prod. 4.	Monitoring isn’t nice to have — it’s your early warning systemTrack feature drift, data anomalies, and performance decay. If your model degrades silently, so does the user experience. 5.	Model versioning and rollback strategies save careersWithout model registries and CI/CD for ML, you’re one bad deploy away from a business incident. 6.	Feedback loops can destroy your dataIf your model influences what data gets collected, retraining on that biased data just amplifies the problem. Design the loop carefully.⸻The takeaway:Production ML isn’t about building smart models — it’s about building resilient systems that adapt, explain, and earn trust.If you’re building AI that survives the real world, I’d love to connect.If you’re hiring — this is the engineering mindset I bring.hashtag#AI hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#MLOps hashtag#FeatureStores hashtag#ModelMonitoring hashtag#ProductionML hashtag#DataScience hashtag#LLMs hashtag#ModelDeployment hashtag#EthicalAI hashtag#PostToSave hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#Python hashtag#TensorFlow hashtag#AIEngineering

Most beginner data analysts focus on tools. The smart ones focus on problems. The best ones focus on impact.If you’re applying for roles in the data analytics space and wondering why your portfolio isn’t getting noticed, read this carefully.A while ago, I was reviewing a job description for a client-side data role. One line caught my attention:➡️ “Use analytics to identify productivity gaps in the frontline sales workforce.”Now, most people would think: “Okay, let me build a dashboard showing number of visits or sales per employee.” And yes, that’s a start, but it’s not value.So I asked myself:📌 What does productivity really mean here?📌 Is it purely about sales numbers or about how many working days were spent effectively?📌 Is there a link between store footfall and visit frequency?📌 What if poor performance isn’t individual, but systemic at the regional or managerial level?That’s when the real project began. Instead of dragging in sample data or public CSVs, I started with a problem definition:“How can we measure Salesforce productivity in context, and not just in aggregate?”Here’s how I broke it down:✅ Compare planned visits (PJP) vs actual visits (AJP)✅ Flag zero-sales days and map against attendance✅ Create a hierarchy-level view — sales rep vs team lead vs regional manager✅ Identify clusters of underperformance✅ Overlay target data to find gaps between activity and outcomeAnd then I asked the golden question:“What would management do with this insight?”The result wasn’t just a dashboard. It was a decision support tool, helping stakeholders:🟢 Prioritize regions for training🟢 Optimize TL-to-employee mapping🟢 Detect ground-level inefficiencies early🟢 Link field behavior to revenue performanceHere’s the lesson:📍 Your project should not just prove you can write SQL or use Power BI.📍 It should prove you understand how businesses think, measure, and act.Start by picking a real business metric, not a dataset. Find a real-world decision problem, and reverse-engineer a solution for it. Frame your project like this:“Here’s the question a stakeholder might ask. Here’s how I’d solve it.”Whether it’s:🔹 Customer retention🔹 Supply chain bottlenecks🔹 Sales effectiveness🔹 Store conversion rate🔹 Marketing ROIYou’re not just an analyst. You’re a problem solver. A business partner. A decision enabler. That’s what hiring managers want to see.Not more dashboards. But more clarity.More thinking.More business fluency.So before your next project… Don’t ask, “What can I build?” Ask, “What problem am I solving?”hashtag#dataanalytics hashtag#dashboard hashtag#powerbi hashtag#dashbaord hashtag#dataanalyst hashtag#businessintelligence

Tired of LeetCode interviews? So are we.Let’s talk about the outdated elephant in the room:Live coding sessions with 2–3 people silently judging your every keystroke while you solve an algorithm you’ll never use on the job.This isn’t just uncomfortable — it’s broken.Here’s the data:According to [HackerRank] only 16% of developers use algorithms like those in LeetCode in real work.A [Karat] survey found 74% of candidates feel more anxious during live coding than any other part of the interview.And the kicker? Great devs fail because of nerves — not lack of skill.Real talk:Building software is not a speed sport ⏱️It’s not about solving red-black trees in 25 minutes.It’s about collaboration 🤝, problem solving 🧠, debugging 🐞, and design 🧱 — plus knowing what to Google 🔍.So why are we still doing this?We need a better way:✅ Async take-home projects (paid, of course)✅ Code reviews with real-world context✅ System design walkthroughs✅ Pair programming — but chill✅ Let devs use their real tools (yes, even Copilot)Let’s stop filtering for “LeetCode athletes” and start hiring real-world engineers.Because if your interview process causes more anxiety than the actual job… you’re doing it wrong.hashtag#NoMoreLeetCodehashtag#TechHiringhashtag#DevCulturehashtag#EngineeringInterviewshashtag#LetDevsBreathehashtag#WorkInTechhashtag#BuildBetterTeams

I recently completed the Data Science assessment for the Data Engineer - Data Warehouse role at IBM India, and I wanted to share a glimpse of the experience. The assessment included two challenging questions that really put my skills to the test. The question involved finding the minimum number of swaps to group like units in a circular network of Compute and Network units. I approached this by calculating the minimum swaps needed to group all Compute units together using a sliding window technique, considering the circular nature of the network. It was a rewarding experience, and I’m feeling more motivated than ever....hashtag#IBM hashtag#DataEngineering hashtag#DataWarehouse hashtag#DataScience hashtag#SQL hashtag#Algorithms hashtag#CareerMilestone hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobOpportunity hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#DataDriven hashtag#Engineering hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth hashtag#LinkedIn hashtag#Networking hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#Technology hashtag#Innovation hashtag#Grateful hashtag#Excited hashtag#FutureOfWork

A decade ago, the roles driving today's AI transformation weren't on anyone's radar. Now they form the backbone of every enterprise AI strategy. As Gartner's analysis reveals, the AI workforce landscape has fundamentally transformed:The foundation remains strong with Data Scientists and Data Engineers continuing to provide critical expertise. Meanwhile, we're witnessing the rapid emergence of specialized roles like Prompt Engineers, Model Validators, and Knowledge Engineers that bridge technical implementation with practical application.Most significantly, organizations can no longer succeed without AI Architects, ML Engineers, and AI Risk & Governance Specialists who ensure systems scale responsibly across the enterprise.The reality of modern AI deployment extends far beyond technical proficiency. Success demands cross-functional collaboration that weaves together business strategy, model development, validation protocols, deployment frameworks, and continuous monitoring systems.Organizations positioned for long-term advantage aren't just hiring technical specialists—they're building integrated teams that balance innovation with operational discipline and ethical governance.For professionals navigating career paths or executives assembling teams, the AI opportunity landscape has expanded dramatically in both scope and complexity. Uncommon Issues in Hiring for the Automotive SectorThe automotive industry encounters distinctive recruitment problems which extend beyond standard skill deficits. The automotive industry faces an uncommon challenge because of its fast transition to electrification which demands knowledge of battery technology and software integration. The lack of specialized skills among experienced automotive engineers produces a significant talent shortage. The reluctance of tech professionals to join traditional automotive companies exists because they prefer working at tech giants which provide remote employment and innovative work environments. The industry faces difficulties in recruiting data scientists and AI experts who are essential for autonomous driving systems because of this perception.The industry faces problems because of differences between generations. The automotive industry faces a challenge because young workers seek roles with sustainability focus and purpose yet they view automotive jobs as traditional and environmentally harmful. This deters passionate candidates. The combination of supply chain disruptions and trade policies restricts the hiring of international talent because certain regions maintain strict visa rules.The market demand for cybersecurity professionals who work on connected vehicles remains unfulfilled because other industries compete more successfully for these experts. The automotive industry needs to transform its branding approach while providing training opportunities and flexible work arrangements to recruit modern talent who will shape the future of the industry.

Username: Jhoshna sai bhargavi ParaJhoshna sai bhargavi Para
Post Content:
Most AI/ML posts talk about accuracy. Real-world AI talks about survival.After deploying multiple models in production, I’ve learned this:A model is not a solution. A system is.Here’s what every experienced ML engineer eventually learns  1.	Clean data beats clever modelsYou can tune hyperparameters all day. Or you can fix broken pipelines and gain 10x accuracy with 1 hour of cleanup. 2.	Feature stores aren’t optional anymoreIf your training and serving pipelines aren’t using the same transformations with point-in-time correctness, you’re risking silent failures. 3.	Offline evaluation ≠ production performanceYour AUC on test data means little if real-time inference suffers from latency, schema mismatches, or concept drift. Always validate in prod. 4.	Monitoring isn’t nice to have — it’s your early warning systemTrack feature drift, data anomalies, and performance decay. If your model degrades silently, so does the user experience. 5.	Model versioning and rollback strategies save careersWithout model registries and CI/CD for ML, you’re one bad deploy away from a business incident. 6.	Feedback loops can destroy your dataIf your model influences what data gets collected, retraining on that biased data just amplifies the problem. Design the loop carefully.⸻The takeaway:Production ML isn’t about building smart models — it’s about building resilient systems that adapt, explain, and earn trust.If you’re building AI that survives the real world, I’d love to connect.If you’re hiring — this is the engineering mindset I bring.hashtag#AI hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#MLOps hashtag#FeatureStores hashtag#ModelMonitoring hashtag#ProductionML hashtag#DataScience hashtag#LLMs hashtag#ModelDeployment hashtag#EthicalAI hashtag#PostToSave hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#Python hashtag#TensorFlow hashtag#AIEngineering

Load balancer – Like a restaurant host assigning tables evenly7. Caching – Saves time like bookmarking a recipe8. CDN – Delivers content from the closest “store”9. Most beginner data analysts focus on tools. The smart ones focus on problems. The best ones focus on impact.If you’re applying for roles in the data analytics space and wondering why your portfolio isn’t getting noticed, read this carefully.A while ago, I was reviewing a job description for a client-side data role. One line caught my attention:➡️ “Use analytics to identify productivity gaps in the frontline sales workforce.”Now, most people would think: “Okay, let me build a dashboard showing number of visits or sales per employee.” And yes, that’s a start, but it’s not value.So I asked myself:📌 What does productivity really mean here?📌 Is it purely about sales numbers or about how many working days were spent effectively?📌 Is there a link between store footfall and visit frequency?📌 What if poor performance isn’t individual, but systemic at the regional or managerial level?That’s when the real project began. Instead of dragging in sample data or public CSVs, I started with a problem definition:“How can we measure Salesforce productivity in context, and not just in aggregate?”Here’s how I broke it down:✅ Compare planned visits (PJP) vs actual visits (AJP)✅ Flag zero-sales days and map against attendance✅ Create a hierarchy-level view — sales rep vs team lead vs regional manager✅ Identify clusters of underperformance✅ Overlay target data to find gaps between activity and outcomeAnd then I asked the golden question:“What would management do with this insight?”The result wasn’t just a dashboard. It was a decision support tool, helping stakeholders:🟢 Prioritize regions for training🟢 Optimize TL-to-employee mapping🟢 Detect ground-level inefficiencies early🟢 Link field behavior to revenue performanceHere’s the lesson:📍 Your project should not just prove you can write SQL or use Power BI.📍 It should prove you understand how businesses think, measure, and act.Start by picking a real business metric, not a dataset. Find a real-world decision problem, and reverse-engineer a solution for it. Frame your project like this:“Here’s the question a stakeholder might ask. Here’s how I’d solve it.”Whether it’s:🔹 Customer retention🔹 Supply chain bottlenecks🔹 Sales effectiveness🔹 Store conversion rate🔹 Marketing ROIYou’re not just an analyst. You’re a problem solver. A business partner. A decision enabler. That’s what hiring managers want to see.Not more dashboards. But more clarity.More thinking.More business fluency.So before your next project… Don’t ask, “What can I build?” Ask, “What problem am I solving?”hashtag#dataanalytics hashtag#dashboard hashtag#powerbi hashtag#dashbaord hashtag#dataanalyst hashtag#businessintelligence

Tired of LeetCode interviews? So are we.Let’s talk about the outdated elephant in the room:Live coding sessions with 2–3 people silently judging your every keystroke while you solve an algorithm you’ll never use on the job.This isn’t just uncomfortable — it’s broken.Here’s the data:According to [HackerRank] only 16% of developers use algorithms like those in LeetCode in real work.A [Karat] survey found 74% of candidates feel more anxious during live coding than any other part of the interview.And the kicker? Great devs fail because of nerves — not lack of skill.Real talk:Building software is not a speed sport ⏱️It’s not about solving red-black trees in 25 minutes.It’s about collaboration 🤝, problem solving 🧠, debugging 🐞, and design 🧱 — plus knowing what to Google 🔍.So why are we still doing this?We need a better way:✅ Async take-home projects (paid, of course)✅ Code reviews with real-world context✅ System design walkthroughs✅ Pair programming — but chill✅ Let devs use their real tools (yes, even Copilot)Let’s stop filtering for “LeetCode athletes” and start hiring real-world engineers.Because if your interview process causes more anxiety than the actual job… you’re doing it wrong.hashtag#NoMoreLeetCodehashtag#TechHiringhashtag#DevCulturehashtag#EngineeringInterviewshashtag#LetDevsBreathehashtag#WorkInTechhashtag#BuildBetterTeams

I recently completed the Data Science assessment for the Data Engineer - Data Warehouse role at IBM India, and I wanted to share a glimpse of the experience. The assessment included two challenging questions that really put my skills to the test. The question involved finding the minimum number of swaps to group like units in a circular network of Compute and Network units. I approached this by calculating the minimum swaps needed to group all Compute units together using a sliding window technique, considering the circular nature of the network. “Building Global Teams? Stop Looking for Mirrors. Start Hiring Multipliers”As a global organization expanding into India through our Global Capability Center, you are not just setting up another satellite office, you're building a strategic, innovation-driven extension of business.That demands a mindset shift, especially when it comes to hiring.Too often, I hear: “They’re not the right culture fit.”And what that often really means is: “They don’t think, speak, or act like we do.”But if we’re going to build truly global teams, that’s not a bug, it’s a feature.We can’t expect to scale innovation while hiring only for alignment with HQ norms.That’s not how you unlock the full potential of a capability center in a talent-rich, perspective-diverse market like India.High-performing teams aren’t built by replicating what we already have. How I caught a £0.40 mistake—and saved the company from losing millions.As a Data Quality Engineer, I’ve always believed that every number tells a story.Recently, while running my routine DQ checks, I spotted a small discrepancy: the online price of a product was £0.40 cheaper than its actual cost. Uncommon Issues in Hiring for the Automotive SectorThe automotive industry encounters distinctive recruitment problems which extend beyond standard skill deficits. The automotive industry faces an uncommon challenge because of its fast transition to electrification which demands knowledge of battery technology and software integration. The lack of specialized skills among experienced automotive engineers produces a significant talent shortage. The reluctance of tech professionals to join traditional automotive companies exists because they prefer working at tech giants which provide remote employment and innovative work environments. The industry faces difficulties in recruiting data scientists and AI experts who are essential for autonomous driving systems because of this perception.The industry faces problems because of differences between generations. The automotive industry faces a challenge because young workers seek roles with sustainability focus and purpose yet they view automotive jobs as traditional and environmentally harmful. This deters passionate candidates. The combination of supply chain disruptions and trade policies restricts the hiring of international talent because certain regions maintain strict visa rules.The market demand for cybersecurity professionals who work on connected vehicles remains unfulfilled because other industries compete more successfully for these experts. The automotive industry needs to transform its branding approach while providing training opportunities and flexible work arrangements to recruit modern talent who will shape the future of the industry.

Username: Jhoshna sai bhargavi ParaJhoshna sai bhargavi Para
Post Content:
Most AI/ML posts talk about accuracy. Real-world AI talks about survival.After deploying multiple models in production, I’ve learned this:A model is not a solution. A system is.Here’s what every experienced ML engineer eventually learns  1.	Clean data beats clever modelsYou can tune hyperparameters all day. Or you can fix broken pipelines and gain 10x accuracy with 1 hour of cleanup. 2.	Feature stores aren’t optional anymoreIf your training and serving pipelines aren’t using the same transformations with point-in-time correctness, you’re risking silent failures. 3.	Offline evaluation ≠ production performanceYour AUC on test data means little if real-time inference suffers from latency, schema mismatches, or concept drift. Always validate in prod. 4.	Monitoring isn’t nice to have — it’s your early warning systemTrack feature drift, data anomalies, and performance decay. If your model degrades silently, so does the user experience. 5.	Model versioning and rollback strategies save careersWithout model registries and CI/CD for ML, you’re one bad deploy away from a business incident. 6.	Feedback loops can destroy your dataIf your model influences what data gets collected, retraining on that biased data just amplifies the problem. Design the loop carefully.⸻The takeaway:Production ML isn’t about building smart models — it’s about building resilient systems that adapt, explain, and earn trust.If you’re building AI that survives the real world, I’d love to connect.If you’re hiring — this is the engineering mindset I bring.hashtag#AI hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#MLOps hashtag#FeatureStores hashtag#ModelMonitoring hashtag#ProductionML hashtag#DataScience hashtag#LLMs hashtag#ModelDeployment hashtag#EthicalAI hashtag#PostToSave hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#Python hashtag#TensorFlow hashtag#AIEngineering

Load balancer – Like a restaurant host assigning tables evenly7. Caching – Saves time like bookmarking a recipe8. CDN – Delivers content from the closest “store”9. Message queues – Like taking a token at a food court10. Using setTimeout() to simulate async behavior? That's an anti-pattern in modern JavaScript.✨ Instead, use Promises or async/await to handle real-world async operations like fetching data, uploading files, or processing payments.👨‍💼 Recruiters want engineers who understand modern asynchronous patterns. Most beginner data analysts focus on tools. The smart ones focus on problems. The best ones focus on impact.If you’re applying for roles in the data analytics space and wondering why your portfolio isn’t getting noticed, read this carefully.A while ago, I was reviewing a job description for a client-side data role. One line caught my attention:➡️ “Use analytics to identify productivity gaps in the frontline sales workforce.”Now, most people would think: “Okay, let me build a dashboard showing number of visits or sales per employee.” And yes, that’s a start, but it’s not value.So I asked myself:📌 What does productivity really mean here?📌 Is it purely about sales numbers or about how many working days were spent effectively?📌 Is there a link between store footfall and visit frequency?📌 What if poor performance isn’t individual, but systemic at the regional or managerial level?That’s when the real project began. Instead of dragging in sample data or public CSVs, I started with a problem definition:“How can we measure Salesforce productivity in context, and not just in aggregate?”Here’s how I broke it down:✅ Compare planned visits (PJP) vs actual visits (AJP)✅ Flag zero-sales days and map against attendance✅ Create a hierarchy-level view — sales rep vs team lead vs regional manager✅ Identify clusters of underperformance✅ Overlay target data to find gaps between activity and outcomeAnd then I asked the golden question:“What would management do with this insight?”The result wasn’t just a dashboard. It was a decision support tool, helping stakeholders:🟢 Prioritize regions for training🟢 Optimize TL-to-employee mapping🟢 Detect ground-level inefficiencies early🟢 Link field behavior to revenue performanceHere’s the lesson:📍 Your project should not just prove you can write SQL or use Power BI.📍 It should prove you understand how businesses think, measure, and act.Start by picking a real business metric, not a dataset. Find a real-world decision problem, and reverse-engineer a solution for it. Frame your project like this:“Here’s the question a stakeholder might ask. Here’s how I’d solve it.”Whether it’s:🔹 Customer retention🔹 Supply chain bottlenecks🔹 Sales effectiveness🔹 Store conversion rate🔹 Marketing ROIYou’re not just an analyst. You’re a problem solver. A business partner. A decision enabler. That’s what hiring managers want to see.Not more dashboards. But more clarity.More thinking.More business fluency.So before your next project… Don’t ask, “What can I build?” Ask, “What problem am I solving?”hashtag#dataanalytics hashtag#dashboard hashtag#powerbi hashtag#dashbaord hashtag#dataanalyst hashtag#businessintelligence

Tired of LeetCode interviews? So are we.Let’s talk about the outdated elephant in the room:Live coding sessions with 2–3 people silently judging your every keystroke while you solve an algorithm you’ll never use on the job.This isn’t just uncomfortable — it’s broken.Here’s the data:According to [HackerRank] only 16% of developers use algorithms like those in LeetCode in real work.A [Karat] survey found 74% of candidates feel more anxious during live coding than any other part of the interview.And the kicker? Great devs fail because of nerves — not lack of skill.Real talk:Building software is not a speed sport ⏱️It’s not about solving red-black trees in 25 minutes.It’s about collaboration 🤝, problem solving 🧠, debugging 🐞, and design 🧱 — plus knowing what to Google 🔍.So why are we still doing this?We need a better way:✅ Async take-home projects (paid, of course)✅ Code reviews with real-world context✅ System design walkthroughs✅ Pair programming — but chill✅ Let devs use their real tools (yes, even Copilot)Let’s stop filtering for “LeetCode athletes” and start hiring real-world engineers.Because if your interview process causes more anxiety than the actual job… you’re doing it wrong.hashtag#NoMoreLeetCodehashtag#TechHiringhashtag#DevCulturehashtag#EngineeringInterviewshashtag#LetDevsBreathehashtag#WorkInTechhashtag#BuildBetterTeams

I recently completed the Data Science assessment for the Data Engineer - Data Warehouse role at IBM India, and I wanted to share a glimpse of the experience. The assessment included two challenging questions that really put my skills to the test. The question involved finding the minimum number of swaps to group like units in a circular network of Compute and Network units. I approached this by calculating the minimum swaps needed to group all Compute units together using a sliding window technique, considering the circular nature of the network. A decade ago, the roles driving today's AI transformation weren't on anyone's radar. Now they form the backbone of every enterprise AI strategy. As Gartner's analysis reveals, the AI workforce landscape has fundamentally transformed:The foundation remains strong with Data Scientists and Data Engineers continuing to provide critical expertise. Meanwhile, we're witnessing the rapid emergence of specialized roles like Prompt Engineers, Model Validators, and Knowledge Engineers that bridge technical implementation with practical application.Most significantly, organizations can no longer succeed without AI Architects, ML Engineers, and AI Risk & Governance Specialists who ensure systems scale responsibly across the enterprise.The reality of modern AI deployment extends far beyond technical proficiency. Uncommon Issues in Hiring for the Automotive SectorThe automotive industry encounters distinctive recruitment problems which extend beyond standard skill deficits. The automotive industry faces an uncommon challenge because of its fast transition to electrification which demands knowledge of battery technology and software integration. The lack of specialized skills among experienced automotive engineers produces a significant talent shortage. The reluctance of tech professionals to join traditional automotive companies exists because they prefer working at tech giants which provide remote employment and innovative work environments. The industry faces difficulties in recruiting data scientists and AI experts who are essential for autonomous driving systems because of this perception.The industry faces problems because of differences between generations. The automotive industry faces a challenge because young workers seek roles with sustainability focus and purpose yet they view automotive jobs as traditional and environmentally harmful. This deters passionate candidates. The combination of supply chain disruptions and trade policies restricts the hiring of international talent because certain regions maintain strict visa rules.The market demand for cybersecurity professionals who work on connected vehicles remains unfulfilled because other industries compete more successfully for these experts. The automotive industry needs to transform its branding approach while providing training opportunities and flexible work arrangements to recruit modern talent who will shape the future of the industry.

Username: Jhoshna sai bhargavi ParaJhoshna sai bhargavi Para
Post Content:
Most AI/ML posts talk about accuracy. Real-world AI talks about survival.After deploying multiple models in production, I’ve learned this:A model is not a solution. A system is.Here’s what every experienced ML engineer eventually learns  1.	Clean data beats clever modelsYou can tune hyperparameters all day. Or you can fix broken pipelines and gain 10x accuracy with 1 hour of cleanup. 2.	Feature stores aren’t optional anymoreIf your training and serving pipelines aren’t using the same transformations with point-in-time correctness, you’re risking silent failures. 3.	Offline evaluation ≠ production performanceYour AUC on test data means little if real-time inference suffers from latency, schema mismatches, or concept drift. Always validate in prod. 4.	Monitoring isn’t nice to have — it’s your early warning systemTrack feature drift, data anomalies, and performance decay. If your model degrades silently, so does the user experience. 5.	Model versioning and rollback strategies save careersWithout model registries and CI/CD for ML, you’re one bad deploy away from a business incident. 6.	Feedback loops can destroy your dataIf your model influences what data gets collected, retraining on that biased data just amplifies the problem. Most beginner data analysts focus on tools. The smart ones focus on problems. The best ones focus on impact.If you’re applying for roles in the data analytics space and wondering why your portfolio isn’t getting noticed, read this carefully.A while ago, I was reviewing a job description for a client-side data role. One line caught my attention:➡️ “Use analytics to identify productivity gaps in the frontline sales workforce.”Now, most people would think: “Okay, let me build a dashboard showing number of visits or sales per employee.” And yes, that’s a start, but it’s not value.So I asked myself:📌 What does productivity really mean here?📌 Is it purely about sales numbers or about how many working days were spent effectively?📌 Is there a link between store footfall and visit frequency?📌 What if poor performance isn’t individual, but systemic at the regional or managerial level?That’s when the real project began. Instead of dragging in sample data or public CSVs, I started with a problem definition:“How can we measure Salesforce productivity in context, and not just in aggregate?”Here’s how I broke it down:✅ Compare planned visits (PJP) vs actual visits (AJP)✅ Flag zero-sales days and map against attendance✅ Create a hierarchy-level view — sales rep vs team lead vs regional manager✅ Identify clusters of underperformance✅ Overlay target data to find gaps between activity and outcomeAnd then I asked the golden question:“What would management do with this insight?”The result wasn’t just a dashboard. It was a decision support tool, helping stakeholders:🟢 Prioritize regions for training🟢 Optimize TL-to-employee mapping🟢 Detect ground-level inefficiencies early🟢 Link field behavior to revenue performanceHere’s the lesson:📍 Your project should not just prove you can write SQL or use Power BI.📍 It should prove you understand how businesses think, measure, and act.Start by picking a real business metric, not a dataset. Find a real-world decision problem, and reverse-engineer a solution for it. Frame your project like this:“Here’s the question a stakeholder might ask. Here’s how I’d solve it.”Whether it’s:🔹 Customer retention🔹 Supply chain bottlenecks🔹 Sales effectiveness🔹 Store conversion rate🔹 Marketing ROIYou’re not just an analyst. You’re a problem solver. A business partner. A decision enabler. That’s what hiring managers want to see.Not more dashboards. But more clarity.More thinking.More business fluency.So before your next project… Don’t ask, “What can I build?” Ask, “What problem am I solving?”hashtag#dataanalytics hashtag#dashboard hashtag#powerbi hashtag#dashbaord hashtag#dataanalyst hashtag#businessintelligence

Tired of LeetCode interviews? So are we.Let’s talk about the outdated elephant in the room:Live coding sessions with 2–3 people silently judging your every keystroke while you solve an algorithm you’ll never use on the job.This isn’t just uncomfortable — it’s broken.Here’s the data:According to [HackerRank] only 16% of developers use algorithms like those in LeetCode in real work.A [Karat] survey found 74% of candidates feel more anxious during live coding than any other part of the interview.And the kicker? Great devs fail because of nerves — not lack of skill.Real talk:Building software is not a speed sport ⏱️It’s not about solving red-black trees in 25 minutes.It’s about collaboration 🤝, problem solving 🧠, debugging 🐞, and design 🧱 — plus knowing what to Google 🔍.So why are we still doing this?We need a better way:✅ Async take-home projects (paid, of course)✅ Code reviews with real-world context✅ System design walkthroughs✅ Pair programming — but chill✅ Let devs use their real tools (yes, even Copilot)Let’s stop filtering for “LeetCode athletes” and start hiring real-world engineers.Because if your interview process causes more anxiety than the actual job… you’re doing it wrong.hashtag#NoMoreLeetCodehashtag#TechHiringhashtag#DevCulturehashtag#EngineeringInterviewshashtag#LetDevsBreathehashtag#WorkInTechhashtag#BuildBetterTeams

“Building Global Teams? Stop Looking for Mirrors. Start Hiring Multipliers”As a global organization expanding into India through our Global Capability Center, you are not just setting up another satellite office, you're building a strategic, innovation-driven extension of business.That demands a mindset shift, especially when it comes to hiring.Too often, I hear: “They’re not the right culture fit.”And what that often really means is: “They don’t think, speak, or act like we do.”But if we’re going to build truly global teams, that’s not a bug, it’s a feature.We can’t expect to scale innovation while hiring only for alignment with HQ norms.That’s not how you unlock the full potential of a capability center in a talent-rich, perspective-diverse market like India.High-performing teams aren’t built by replicating what we already have. 🔍 Data-Driven Decision Making in Audit Leveraging data to improve audit quality and insightsIn today’s fast-paced, tech-enabled environment, data-driven auditing is no longer optional — it's essential.Auditors can now harness data analytics to uncover patterns, detect anomalies, and perform risk-based audits with greater depth, speed, and accuracy.✅ Example: Rather than testing a sample of 50 sales transactions, a data-enabled audit allows us to analyze 100% of transactions for unusual patterns — say, sales just below approval thresholds or payments made on weekends. This reveals risks that traditional sampling may overlook.🎯 The Result?Better risk identificationImproved audit efficiencyDeeper client insightsStronger decision-making support💡 Tip: Start small. Use Excel, Power BI, or audit tools like IDEA/ACL to automate routine checks and visualize trends.Audit is evolving. How I caught a £0.40 mistake—and saved the company from losing millions.As a Data Quality Engineer, I’ve always believed that every number tells a story.Recently, while running my routine DQ checks, I spotted a small discrepancy: the online price of a product was £0.40 cheaper than its actual cost. It seemed minor—but my instincts said otherwise.I didn’t ignore it.Instead, I ran my custom validation logic across real-time datasets and found two products inaccurately priced. Left unchecked, this could have silently caused the company to bleed millions over time.I took swift action:Identified the root causeValidated impacted datasets and columnsHelped the team correct the issue immediatelyLesson Learned:- Data quality isn’t just about accuracy—it’s about preventing catastrophic losses before they happen.esson learnt:- This wasn’t just about data—it was about ownership, precision, and value.It’s these small wins that remind me why I love what I do.hashtag#DataQualityMatters hashtag#RealTimeAnalytics hashtag#ETLTesting hashtag#BusinessImpact hashtag#DataSavesMoney hashtag#DataWithPurpose hashtag#LifeOfADataEngineer

Uncommon Issues in Hiring for the Automotive SectorThe automotive industry encounters distinctive recruitment problems which extend beyond standard skill deficits. The automotive industry faces an uncommon challenge because of its fast transition to electrification which demands knowledge of battery technology and software integration. The lack of specialized skills among experienced automotive engineers produces a significant talent shortage. The reluctance of tech professionals to join traditional automotive companies exists because they prefer working at tech giants which provide remote employment and innovative work environments. The industry faces difficulties in recruiting data scientists and AI experts who are essential for autonomous driving systems because of this perception.The industry faces problems because of differences between generations. The automotive industry faces a challenge because young workers seek roles with sustainability focus and purpose yet they view automotive jobs as traditional and environmentally harmful. This deters passionate candidates. The combination of supply chain disruptions and trade policies restricts the hiring of international talent because certain regions maintain strict visa rules.The market demand for cybersecurity professionals who work on connected vehicles remains unfulfilled because other industries compete more successfully for these experts. Username: Jhoshna sai bhargavi ParaJhoshna sai bhargavi Para
Post Content:
Most AI/ML posts talk about accuracy. Real-world AI talks about survival.After deploying multiple models in production, I’ve learned this:A model is not a solution. A system is.Here’s what every experienced ML engineer eventually learns  1.	Clean data beats clever modelsYou can tune hyperparameters all day. Or you can fix broken pipelines and gain 10x accuracy with 1 hour of cleanup. 2.	Feature stores aren’t optional anymoreIf your training and serving pipelines aren’t using the same transformations with point-in-time correctness, you’re risking silent failures. 3.	Offline evaluation ≠ production performanceYour AUC on test data means little if real-time inference suffers from latency, schema mismatches, or concept drift. Always validate in prod. 4.	Monitoring isn’t nice to have — it’s your early warning systemTrack feature drift, data anomalies, and performance decay. If your model degrades silently, so does the user experience. 5.	Model versioning and rollback strategies save careersWithout model registries and CI/CD for ML, you’re one bad deploy away from a business incident. 6.	Feedback loops can destroy your dataIf your model influences what data gets collected, retraining on that biased data just amplifies the problem. Design the loop carefully.⸻The takeaway:Production ML isn’t about building smart models — it’s about building resilient systems that adapt, explain, and earn trust.If you’re building AI that survives the real world, I’d love to connect.If you’re hiring — this is the engineering mindset I bring.hashtag#AI hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#MLOps hashtag#FeatureStores hashtag#ModelMonitoring hashtag#ProductionML hashtag#DataScience hashtag#LLMs hashtag#ModelDeployment hashtag#EthicalAI hashtag#PostToSave hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#Python hashtag#TensorFlow hashtag#AIEngineering

Most beginner data analysts focus on tools. The smart ones focus on problems. The best ones focus on impact.If you’re applying for roles in the data analytics space and wondering why your portfolio isn’t getting noticed, read this carefully.A while ago, I was reviewing a job description for a client-side data role. One line caught my attention:➡️ “Use analytics to identify productivity gaps in the frontline sales workforce.”Now, most people would think: “Okay, let me build a dashboard showing number of visits or sales per employee.” And yes, that’s a start, but it’s not value.So I asked myself:📌 What does productivity really mean here?📌 Is it purely about sales numbers or about how many working days were spent effectively?📌 Is there a link between store footfall and visit frequency?📌 What if poor performance isn’t individual, but systemic at the regional or managerial level?That’s when the real project began. Instead of dragging in sample data or public CSVs, I started with a problem definition:“How can we measure Salesforce productivity in context, and not just in aggregate?”Here’s how I broke it down:✅ Compare planned visits (PJP) vs actual visits (AJP)✅ Flag zero-sales days and map against attendance✅ Create a hierarchy-level view — sales rep vs team lead vs regional manager✅ Identify clusters of underperformance✅ Overlay target data to find gaps between activity and outcomeAnd then I asked the golden question:“What would management do with this insight?”The result wasn’t just a dashboard. It was a decision support tool, helping stakeholders:🟢 Prioritize regions for training🟢 Optimize TL-to-employee mapping🟢 Detect ground-level inefficiencies early🟢 Link field behavior to revenue performanceHere’s the lesson:📍 Your project should not just prove you can write SQL or use Power BI.📍 It should prove you understand how businesses think, measure, and act.Start by picking a real business metric, not a dataset. Find a real-world decision problem, and reverse-engineer a solution for it. Frame your project like this:“Here’s the question a stakeholder might ask. Here’s how I’d solve it.”Whether it’s:🔹 Customer retention🔹 Supply chain bottlenecks🔹 Sales effectiveness🔹 Store conversion rate🔹 Marketing ROIYou’re not just an analyst. You’re a problem solver. A business partner. A decision enabler. That’s what hiring managers want to see.Not more dashboards. But more clarity.More thinking.More business fluency.So before your next project… Don’t ask, “What can I build?” Ask, “What problem am I solving?”hashtag#dataanalytics hashtag#dashboard hashtag#powerbi hashtag#dashbaord hashtag#dataanalyst hashtag#businessintelligence

Tired of LeetCode interviews? So are we.Let’s talk about the outdated elephant in the room:Live coding sessions with 2–3 people silently judging your every keystroke while you solve an algorithm you’ll never use on the job.This isn’t just uncomfortable — it’s broken.Here’s the data:According to [HackerRank] only 16% of developers use algorithms like those in LeetCode in real work.A [Karat] survey found 74% of candidates feel more anxious during live coding than any other part of the interview.And the kicker? Great devs fail because of nerves — not lack of skill.Real talk:Building software is not a speed sport ⏱️It’s not about solving red-black trees in 25 minutes.It’s about collaboration 🤝, problem solving 🧠, debugging 🐞, and design 🧱 — plus knowing what to Google 🔍.So why are we still doing this?We need a better way:✅ Async take-home projects (paid, of course)✅ Code reviews with real-world context✅ System design walkthroughs✅ Pair programming — but chill✅ Let devs use their real tools (yes, even Copilot)Let’s stop filtering for “LeetCode athletes” and start hiring real-world engineers.Because if your interview process causes more anxiety than the actual job… you’re doing it wrong.hashtag#NoMoreLeetCodehashtag#TechHiringhashtag#DevCulturehashtag#EngineeringInterviewshashtag#LetDevsBreathehashtag#WorkInTechhashtag#BuildBetterTeams

I recently completed the Data Science assessment for the Data Engineer - Data Warehouse role at IBM India, and I wanted to share a glimpse of the experience. The assessment included two challenging questions that really put my skills to the test. The question involved finding the minimum number of swaps to group like units in a circular network of Compute and Network units. I approached this by calculating the minimum swaps needed to group all Compute units together using a sliding window technique, considering the circular nature of the network. It was a rewarding experience, and I’m feeling more motivated than ever....hashtag#IBM hashtag#DataEngineering hashtag#DataWarehouse hashtag#DataScience hashtag#SQL hashtag#Algorithms hashtag#CareerMilestone hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobOpportunity hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#DataDriven hashtag#Engineering hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth hashtag#LinkedIn hashtag#Networking hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#Technology hashtag#Innovation hashtag#Grateful hashtag#Excited hashtag#FutureOfWork

A decade ago, the roles driving today's AI transformation weren't on anyone's radar. Now they form the backbone of every enterprise AI strategy. As Gartner's analysis reveals, the AI workforce landscape has fundamentally transformed:The foundation remains strong with Data Scientists and Data Engineers continuing to provide critical expertise. Meanwhile, we're witnessing the rapid emergence of specialized roles like Prompt Engineers, Model Validators, and Knowledge Engineers that bridge technical implementation with practical application.Most significantly, organizations can no longer succeed without AI Architects, ML Engineers, and AI Risk & Governance Specialists who ensure systems scale responsibly across the enterprise.The reality of modern AI deployment extends far beyond technical proficiency. Success demands cross-functional collaboration that weaves together business strategy, model development, validation protocols, deployment frameworks, and continuous monitoring systems.Organizations positioned for long-term advantage aren't just hiring technical specialists—they're building integrated teams that balance innovation with operational discipline and ethical governance.For professionals navigating career paths or executives assembling teams, the AI opportunity landscape has expanded dramatically in both scope and complexity. Post Content:
🔍 Data-Driven Decision Making in Audit Leveraging data to improve audit quality and insightsIn today’s fast-paced, tech-enabled environment, data-driven auditing is no longer optional — it's essential.Auditors can now harness data analytics to uncover patterns, detect anomalies, and perform risk-based audits with greater depth, speed, and accuracy.✅ Example: Rather than testing a sample of 50 sales transactions, a data-enabled audit allows us to analyze 100% of transactions for unusual patterns — say, sales just below approval thresholds or payments made on weekends. This reveals risks that traditional sampling may overlook.🎯 The Result?Better risk identificationImproved audit efficiencyDeeper client insightsStronger decision-making support💡 Tip: Start small. Use Excel, Power BI, or audit tools like IDEA/ACL to automate routine checks and visualize trends.Audit is evolving. Are you evolving with it?hashtag#AuditInnovation hashtag#DataAnalytics hashtag#InternalAudit hashtag#ICAN hashtag#AuditQuality hashtag#RiskManagement hashtag#DataDriven hashtag#LinkedInLearning
